content.question: A student builds the apparatus shown above. A light string is attached to an object of unknown mass and passed through a tube such that the other end of the string is attached to a second object of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></math>. By holding on to the tube, the student swings the object of unknown mass in a horizontal circle of radius <math alttext="lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> while the object of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></math> hanging from the string remains at a constant height. In each trial, the radius <math alttext="lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></math> of the circular path is changed and the tangential speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>ν</mi></mrow></math> of the object of unknown mass is calculated. How can the student determine the value of the unknown mass by using the radius of its circular path and its speed?

Use the slope of a graph of <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>ν</mi></mrow></math> as a function of <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></math>.
